title: Creative Studio Lighting with Mylar Sheets
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler demonstrates how to use crumpled Mylar sheets to create a water-like reflection effect in studio photography. She breaks down a simple one-light setup using hard light and an advanced three-light setup incorporating colored gels and a star filter.

steps.action: Prepare the Mylar sheet by crumpling it up rather than laying it flat. This creates multiple surfaces for the light to reflect off, mimicking the texture of water.

Set up the one-light configuration. Place the subject on the Mylar and use a hard light source (Fresnel) pointed at the Mylar in front of the subject, rather than directly at them, to bounce light and create texture.
Post-process the single-light image. Clean up background creases, desaturate the image for an elegant look, and use curves to brighten the face.
Transition to a three-light setup. Keep the main Fresnel light, but add gels to fill in shadows and background.
Attach a star filter to the camera lens. Combined with the hard light and a sparkly dress, this creates specular highlights for a fantasy look.

Position the secondary lights. Place a medium umbrella with a blue gel in the front right to fill shadows, and a large umbrella with a magenta gel behind the subject for rim light and background color.
Post-process the three-light image. Change the white balance to Tungsten to cool the image significantly, then desaturate to control the intensity of the blue for a mysterious 'underwater' vibe.

key_takeaways: Smooth Mylar acts like a mirror; crumpled Mylar creates texture that mimics water.
Hard light sources (like Fresnels) are essential for creating crisp reflections on textured surfaces.
Point the key light at the reflective surface in front of the subject to bounce light onto them.
Gels are most effective when used to fill shadow areas.
Star filters require hard light and specular highlights (like sequins) to work effectively.
Drastic white balance changes (e.g., switching to Tungsten) can be used creatively to alter the mood of a scene.
